rename.from: splitChunks does not add required dependencies into common chunk
rename.to: splitChunks with innerGraph does not add required dependencies into common chunk

body: setting `optimization.innerGraph = false` prevents the problem - and gets both dep1 and dep2 added to the commons chunk. or adds dep2 to both index1 and index2 if I set the commons to explicitly only include dep1 (instead of all modules in more than one entry).

i can reproduce it

https://github.com/Knagis/webpack-concat-issue/blob/c46dfd7cdfee8d301547a32417ca825c343e398e/dist/main2.js#L35

`__webpack_modules__` in main2.js only contains 51 and 113 but gets called with 891 
```
__webpack_modules__
{…}
​
51: function 51(__unused_webpack_module, __unused_webpack___webpack_exports__, __webpack_require__)​
113: function 113(__unused_webpack_module, __webpack_exports__, __webpack_require__)​
<prototype>: Object { … }

moduleId
891
__webpack_modules__[moduleId]
undefined
```

hmm, yes that's a tricky case... The import is actually unused in `index2`, but merging the two variants of `dep1` into a common variant (shared by both runtimes) generates an invalid `__webpack_require__(891)`.

We probably need to generate some code to conditionally import the dependencies depending on runtime, so these forcefully shared modules can be generated correctly.

There are multiple workaround possible:
* no `name` for `splitChunks` to avoid forcing them to merge
* `optimization.usedExports: "global"` to disable runtime-dependent exports
* `optimization.innerGraph: false` to disable import usage tracking
* `optimization.sideEffects: false` to disable side-effect-free modules which cause the dependency dropping

issue.title: generate code that executes depending on runtime

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

body:
There is a bugfix here: https://github.com/webpack/webpack/pull/11802
but I'm unsure if this has more undiscovered side effects...

Maybe you can test the PR in your real repos, that would give me more certainty that it works fine?

You can just reference a branch in your package.json `"webpack": "webpack/webpack#bugfix/11770"`
will do. hopefully during weekend, if not, on Monday.

Yep, thanks that helped. I updated the PR with a fix for that and a few other fixes I discovered. If you have some time it would be cool to test the PR again. If it works for you, I would publish a new webpack version for this.

I have now tested the update PR and the `TypeError: str.replace is not a function` have disappeared but unfortunately the generated bundle does still not run. Interestingly the bundle did work before when using the `optimization.sideEffects: false` option but now also fails with this option.

The error stack looks like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1009585/97203742-88687a80-17b5-11eb-8b51-b0bfa3e05d0f.png)

The actual code where the error is reported `UiElementFile.ts:33` looks like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1009585/97203926-c2d21780-17b5-11eb-982d-38c535a466b1.png)

And this is the `bootstrap:18` code:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1009585/97204167-0b89d080-17b6-11eb-8ba5-3f00a8f95975.png)

Is there anything I can do to help?
In my case the error I used to get due to the common chunk seems to be fixed in the branch, that is, now everything builds and works correctly even with enabled innerGraph.

@doberkofler did you try using `innerGraph: false` as a workaround? That is how I worked around the issue in my repo and it seems to be better than completely turning off sideEffects - at least compared to webpack 4 there wouldn't be a loss of optimizations.
I have also tried `innerGraph: false` but it still generated a bundle does not run. Maybe I'm hitting a different bug?
